sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Hello and welcome to Euronews tonight. Our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: God save the Queen. Four-day Platinum Jubilee celebrations kick off to honour Elizabeth II's 70 years on the British throne.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Amid the festivities, social media users are angry about the price tag of the Jubilee. But what is the real cost for UK taxpayers? After almost 100 days of war, Russian forces now control one-fifth of Ukraine's territory, President Zelensky says.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And Hungary's happy hold-up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: EU countries take Russian Orthodox leader off sanctions list to get Budapest's approval.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Welcome to the program. I'm Stefan Grobe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The Queen of England is marking 70 years since her accession to the throne,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: making her the longest reigning monarch in British history.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And festivities have already started in the UK as part of an extended special four-day weekend.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Thomas Hill has the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: four-day weekend. Thomas Hill has the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: A family affair and a national celebration. The first of four days marking 70 years of Queen Elizabeth's reign. Four generations looking up from the palace as the Royal Air Force painted its tribute across London's skies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: painted its tribute across London's skies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Cheers for the 96-year-old monarch momentarily drowned out by booms of a gun salute.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Earlier, the festivities were launched by the spectacular Trooping the Colour parade within sight of the palace.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Britain has been preparing for this moment for years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: People came from all parts of the country and beyond to be at the heart of events.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Yes, these countries are getting independence, but we've still got our money, we've still got our cream, which is a wonderful thing to have, a precious thing that every country should have.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: When she first became the Queen, she pledged her life to our country, and she has honoured that pledge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Amid a hard-hitting cost-of-living crisis, the Platinum Jubilee Party offers a welcome distraction for many.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: It also shows the Queen's enduring popularity after 70 years on the throne.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Let's cross to our reporter Victoria Smith in London, who was in the thick of it all today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Good evening, Victoria.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So it was an extraordinary moment for British monarchy today. Talk about the atmosphere around you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Hi, Stefan. Yeah, well, thousands of people have descended on central London from all over the country and from all over the world as well. There's a whole stream of people walking past in front of me. I'll show you in a minute. This is as close to the palace as we're allowed to get.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Security is tight, but very friendly. You can just see the hoardings going up behind me, the Victoria Monument just about visible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And this tree that you can see right at the edge of the picture, this is the largest beacon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: This is a 21-meter-high beacon that's going to be lit tonight, as well as thousands of others across the country and in Commonwealth countries as well. Those beacons will be lit as a symbol of gratitude, a symbol of honor to the Queen, who, as you said, this is an unprecedented event, 70 years on the throne. We have never seen anything like this before.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We may never see anything like this again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I will just turn the camera now just to show you the people just keep coming. They have been here all day. They are coming from the park. They're walking past, many of them brightly dressed from all over the world as well. So they just keep streaming down here near Buckingham Palace, taking part in the day. And I spoke to a couple of people earlier on and they told me what they thought of the whole Jubilee celebrations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: jubilee celebrations. We had fun. We'd come up from South London, we stood on the steps by Trafalgar Square and saw the flyover, which was really spectacular. And then we went for lunch and we just had a little walk down the mountain, taking the scene and the flags. It was really great.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Lovely mix of people, great atmosphere and had a lot of fun.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Victoria the Queen has had her family around her, but not everybody joined her on the balcony.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Who was absent and why?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Yeah, excellent question, Stefan.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, she had her close family around her.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The way they dealt with the situation about Prince Andrew and Harry and Meghan was to say that only working royals would appear on the balcony.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And that was the case.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And, of course, Harry, Meghan and Prince Andrew are no longer working royals would appear on the balcony. And that was the case. And of course, Harry, Meghan and Prince Andrew are no longer working royals. So an elegant solution, perhaps, to a difficult question. And we've heard as well this evening that Prince Andrew won't be attending the ceremony at St. Paul's tomorrow, the service of Thanksgiving, because he has apparently tested for Covid. So a scaled down royal family on the balcony. But it was good to see the Queen there. There was some doubt as to whether she would actually attend. But there she was with a walking stick. And she appeared, of course, to watch the fly past with the jets overhead. The jets actually spelling out 70, 7-0. Of course, the number of years the Queen's been on the throne. She was there for that spectacle with the close members of her family, too.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I have to ask you that the Queen is obviously hugely popular in Britain and beyond.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Will Charles ever move the masses like her one day?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, of course, he has already, to some extent, started taking over.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He was the one who inspected the troops today for the Trooping of the Colour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: That's normally the Queen's job.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He was the one mixing with the crowds near Buckingham Palace.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And he, of course, has done quite a lot of this sort of thing recently.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He was there in attendance at the state opening of Parliament when the Queen was unable to attend because of her mobility issues, her general health. So already he is moving into that position.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Whether he'll capture the nation's heart, the nation's mind as much as the Queen has, we have to wait and see. Certainly the numbers of people here today and the sheer spectacle and expense of the events over the next four days shows how loved Her Majesty is, not by everyone, but certainly by the hordes of people here today, and certainly 70 years on the throne, unprecedented, and that's why we're having this huge jubilee celebration.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: All right, Victoria Smith in London, thank you very much and keep it up until Sunday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Although the popularity of the Queen remains high, hundreds of social media users have expressed their anger over the cost of the celebration.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Matthew in the Cube has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, Stefan, the UK government has promised a once-in-a-generation show to celebrate Queen Elizabeth II's 70 years on the throne, with a four-day weekend of processions, parties, pageantry and prayers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But amid all the festivities, there are murmurs and misleading rumours online. What is the

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: cost of the Platinum Jubilee to everyday UK taxpayers?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Some people on Twitter have been stating things like this that to put together the event it costs around 1 billion pounds or around 38,000 pounds for each UK taxpayer. That's around 44,000 euros. Some people expressing anger at the cost and price tag of the event given that the UK economy has suffered from the Covid-19 pandemic and the war in Ukraine. But these claims are misleading. Firstly, on the maths, if you divide £1 billion by the around 30 million UK taxpayers or households, you won't get £38,000, you'll get something closer to £30. And what's more, even though we don't know the true cost of the Platinum Jubilee celebrations, it is not to believe to be anywhere near the £1 billion that is being claimed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Last year, the UK's Department for Digital Culture, Media and Sport said on a statement that £28 million would be set aside for the Queen's Platinum Jubilee celebrations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This number was again quoted by Chancellor Rishi Sunak when he announced the budget.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And it's also important to note that this £ million pounds isn't going to be just borne by the UK taxpayer. Some of it will come from partner organisations like the UK's National Lottery. Now the figure of 1 billion pounds has been mentioned before when it comes to Queen Elizabeth II and celebrations but this specifically relates to the cost to the UK's economy rather than the cost to taxpayers or the cost of the event itself. In truth, Stefan, this year that could be estimated to be a loss of the UK economy of £2.3 billion. But regardless, when you boil that down, the platinum celebrations for Queen Elizabeth are certainly not going to cost each individual taxpayer in the UK tens of thousands of pounds.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: All right, Matthew in the queue cube there. Thank you very much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: President Volodymyr Zelensky says Russia now controls 20% of Ukraine's territory as Russian forces continue to make advances on the Eastern Front.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Zelensky said defense forces are encountering ferocious Russian attacks and suffering losses of up to 100 soldiers a day. UK military intelligence reports that Moscow now occupies most of Ukraine's key eastern city of Severodonetsk, where civilians are seeking shelter beneath a chemical plant.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Local officials expect Russia's offensive to soon veer south in an effort to capture cities in the Donetsk region.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Kiev says 243 children have been killed and over 200,000 forcefully taken to Russia since the start of the invasion. In an address to Luxembourg's parliament, President Zelensky accused Moscow of seeking to disassociate children from their Ukrainian heritage.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The UN says the war in Ukraine has displaced almost 15 million people, over 5 million of whom have fled the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Addressing world leaders at the Globsec annual forum in Blatislava, Volodymyr Zelenskyy expressed gratitude for the continued support for his country and emphasized the importance of sustaining Ukraine's morale.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Weapons are the top priority. Weapons are different.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We are talking not only about artillery rounds, we are not talking solely about rocket systems.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: We are also talking about the weapons which are uniting our people because taken a low the the unity of Ukrainian people is the most important weapon of every country in the world therefore unifying the people depends on the motivation when the whole world is looking at us and is supporting us is a great motivation joining me now is our correspondent Sasha vaculina who is in Bratislava for us good evening Sasha good to see you there so is Zelensky satisfied with the amount of Western military support Ukraine is getting? Did he say anything?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He did, Stefan. Indeed, he was the first person to address the Globesec audience and the European leaders who are here in Bratislava. And he said, indeed, Ukraine is very grateful. He thanked everybody in the room and not here present for sending those weapons but he said more is needed and he asked the Allies to step up their efforts and to send more giving the example he said that Ukraine has made great advances around Kharkiv region that's northeast of Ukraine but the situation in the east remains dying he said around hundred people are dying per day and about 450 or 500 people are being injured in the east every day.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And to change that, what Ukraine needs first and foremost is weapons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He said that this is the motivation, as you've heard there from Volodymyr Zelensky.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He said as long as the world supports Ukraine, Ukraine will have this motivation to fight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And what about the Russian sanctions?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Does he think that Europe is doing enough? Well, that was the second priority on his list. The second issue that he's talked about here, he said that sanctions, again, are useful. He's praised the sixth package. But he said that it takes too much time to agree on those packages.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He said, look at how much time it's taken to agree on the sixth package. And the other one should be already in preparations. It should take less time. It should be faster and a quicker process because he said when it comes to the sanctions, they do work not only to harm Russia, but also to make sure Europe, European Union, does not depend on Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And also, of course, talking about the European Union, he also mentioned the third priority of his address here in Globe Second.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: That was Ukraine's chances to become the candidate for the membership of the European Union.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He said that Ukrainians have already paid a very steep price, showing how much they are willing to join the European Union. And he said Europe should see us as an equal partner. The status is very important for Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Speaking after Zelensky was the European Commission president, Ruslana Vondelena, and she commented on this very statement, saying that in Brussels they have heard very well that Ukraine wants to be part of the European family.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: She also said that not only is the EU's strategic interest, but also it is the European Union's moral duty.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But, of course, she touched upon the issue of the so-called shortcut and whether this is something that could be possible for Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: She said, no, there will be no shortcut for Ukraine or anyone else. But according to us of until late what happens here is when the country wants to join the European Union how quickly and how efficient that could happen depends on two things on these countries efforts to join the European Union and all the EU support of those efforts of a country who wants to join the EU. All right, Sasha Vakulina in Bratislava.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Thank you very much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: After a long diplomatic effort, the EU has approved its sixth sanction package against Russia, but it has dropped the head of the Russian Orthodox Church from its blacklist.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Budapest had held up the latest round of punitive measures because of the addition of the patriarch Kirill to the bloc's list.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Kirill is considered an ally of Russian President Vladimir Putin and is a vocal supporter of the war in Ukraine. Sanctions include a ban on purchasing seaborne Russian oil within six to eight months. Now let's turn to our correspondent Efi Kutsukosta, who is in Brussels for us with more on that story. Good evening Efi, good to see you there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So the sanctions have finally passed but they had to overcome Hungarian objections again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Why is it that Budapest was so interested in not punishing the Orthodox leader?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: punishing the Orthodox leader?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: That's a good question, Stefan.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Actually, nobody knows why.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The official response, the official answer from the Hungarian government is that they respect the freedom of religion and that's why they shouldn't include a religious leader, let's say, into the list of sanctions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Of course, everybody knows that the EU wanted to include the patriarchal into the sanctions because he's not serving for many times as a religious leader he's not neutral he's very close to put into Vladimir Putin he's even using Kremlin's language when it comes to Russia's invasion of Ukraine he's describing it as a special military operation, as the Kremlin does, and not as a war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Of course, many diplomats are not happy with what happened again with Hungary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: They said they couldn't do anything now because they wanted to approve this package.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It's already one month and more that it's hostage.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: They describe this Hungarian policy as a hostage policy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: One other diplomat told me that Hungary is very much isolated on an EU level, but in reality, Hungary, this time, the Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban got exactly what he wanted.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And can this change? It could change only if the treaty changes, because this kind of decisions of foreign policy can be taken only unanimously on an EU level.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: A question on Poland. Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president, was there today to sign off on the release of recovery funds. Does that mean that all the rule of law issues are solved now?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Of course not. They are not solved.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Actually, last October, Ursula von der Leyen set three conditions in order to unlock the Polish recovery plan, which has to do with the judiciary system. First was dismantling the disciplinary chamber in Poland's Supreme Court.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The second one was to change the disciplinary chamber in Poland's Supreme Court the second one was to change the disciplinary system and third to reinstate judges suspended under the current rules Poland recently in a move to unlock the recovery funds just voted a law which dismantles this disciplinary chamber of Poland's Supreme Court but just that the opposition and several human rights organizations said that these are just cosmetical changes and the Polish government didn't go far. But even inside the College of the EU commissioners which saw several different voices at least two vice presidents of the EU commission from Steemermans and Margaret of the stagger voted against the presidents of the EU Commission, Franz Timmermans and Margrethe Vestager, voted against the approval of the Polish recovery plan.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Actually, it's obvious that the EU Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, wants to end the dispute with Poland, a key country neighbouring to Ukraine, which is offering shelter to almost 3.6 million Ukrainian refugees. And this money, these recovery funds, can be used not only for the energy transition of the country, but also to help the entry of Ukrainians into the labor market. But of course, as an EU official was explaining to us, this doesn't mean that the EU Commission or Brussels will give fresh cash for free to Poland. It's a step-by-step process.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: As it happens with all member states and the recovery fund, they will be given grants and loans only if they deliver their promises.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So the EU Commission will finally decide late June or July whether they finally unlock the funds for Poland or not.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: All right, Ifikutsu Kosta in Brussels. Thank you very much for these updates.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: A global summit is taking place in Brussels to discuss measures which can address and prevent online child abuse, with recent figures describing a worrying upwards trend and illicit imagery being circulated online. Christopher Pichas reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: 85 million child pornography images were found to be circulating on the web last year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Studies suggest that since 2010 there's been a 6,000 percent increase. It's one of the reasons why in Brussels on Wednesday and Thursday governments and civil society as well technology companies, met for a global summit to combat online child abuse.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But whatever the crime, victims who dared to speak out say they want to be heard because the trauma is all too painful.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Like many survivors, I lived in fear and in silence for a long time. But I'm also one of the few lucky ones, because eventually I had access to resources and help and support that allowed me to be who I am today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: At 47, Daniela Ligiero is no longer afraid to speak out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: This former member of the Obama administration was abused from the age of six by a close relative.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But it was just when she was a teenager that she from the age of six by a close relative.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But it was just when she was a teenager that she had the courage to confide in her parents. She now calls on victims to speak out despite the scars that mark them for life.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: I think there's a lot of stigma and shame still, and there's this sense that this is something that happens somewhere else, not in our families, not in our communities, and that it's small. But the reality is, it's huge. We know from data that approximately 1 in 4 girls and 1 in 8 boys around the world will experience some form of sexual violence as children. And so there are many of us, but most of us are hidden.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: UNICEF points out that online child abuse is a recent phenomenon, only a decade old.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But the consequences are lifelong since there's no such thing as forgetting about it on the web.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So we're talking about millions of images of children who continues to be circulated and when this image is recirculated that is they're re-traumatizing the child.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The child can never get rid of these images.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Imagine you were abused in your childhood, and as you grow up as a person, that image is still out there circulating about you, always.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's endless. It's immortal. It never goes away.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Last month, Brussels proposed measures to push technology companies to better target these types of images and predators. But the most important thing for all abuse victims is that justice is served no matter how long it takes. Chris Lepitch is your news, Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The Alliance of Oil Producing Countries, OPEC, which includes Russia, has announced they will raise production by more than 640,000 barrels per day in July and August.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The move is likely to offer modest relief for global economies suffering from soaring energy prices and inflation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It comes as rising crude prices have pushed petrol to a record high in many countries around the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Experts fear elevated energy prices could slow the global economy as it emerges from the pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Participants in Yemen's civil war have agreed to extend the nationwide truce for another two months, according to the UN. The original ceasefire came into effect on April 2, the first nationwide truce in six years. However, both the Houthi rebels and Yemen's government have accused the other of violating the agreement.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: That's it for this edition.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Thank you for watching.
